awd_titl_txt: Jets as Probes of Ultra-Relativistic Heavy-Ion Collisions
awd_abstract_narration:
For several microseconds after the big bang the entire universe passed through a phase called the Quark-Gluon Plasma (QGP).  More than a million times hotter than the sun, the QGP is a form of matter governed by quantum chromodynamics (QCD) where the individual quarks and gluons localized within nucleons are expected to scatter out over distances and times many times larger than a femtometer (fm).  Only in the last ten years has it become possible to create and study this form of matter in the laboratory using the fleetingly short-lived nuclear sized droplets of plasma created in the aftermath of a heavy-ion collision.  The very short lifetime (10 fm/c, where c is the speed of light) and small size (10 fm) have made the study of this matter a theoretical and experimental challenge.  The modification of hard QCD jets (bundles of strongly interacting particles) as they pass through this exotic form of matter presents the best tool to date to study the various properties of the QGP.  The goal of the research supported by this grant is to continue to formulate both a systematic and sophisticated approach to the theoretical study of these modified jets.  Considerable effort will be directed towards a deeper understanding of the factorization of the hard jet cascade from the soft rescattering experienced by the patrons in the jet, as they propagate through the QGP.  Yet another goal will be to numerically simulate the partonic cascade process within the dense medium to better understand the event-by-event characteristics of such modified showers.  A third goal will be a rigorous analysis of the data within the framework of perturbative QCD based jet modification to isolate the transport properties of the plasma and place stringent error bars on the extracted transport coefficients of jets in a QGP.

This research, at the intersection of particle and nuclear physics, will greatly enhance our understanding of perturbative and non-perturbative QCD in the complicated environments of a dynamically expanding quark gluon plasma. It will introduce state of the art numerical tools to simulate such processes.  It will lead to the training of graduate students in both the sophisticated analytical approaches used as well as the numerical simulation tools used in such efforts. The project also includes an outreach effort to convey the latest results from such analyses as well as from other new cutting edge fields to the general public.

por.por_cntn:
Microseconds after the Big Bang, at ambient temperatures above a trillion degrees, the universe was filled with a fluid-like state made up of quarks and gluons, called the Quark Gluon Plasma (QGP). This fluid expanded through the nascent universe with a viscosity that was just barely higher than the minimum allowed by quantum mechanics. Tiny droplets of this substance are now routinely created in the collision of large nuclei such as Gold at the Relativistic Heavy-Ion Collider (RHIC) at Brookhaven National Laboratory, and Lead at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN in Geneva. Once formed, these droplets undergo explosive expansion and evaporate into conventional matter within 10-23 seconds. This makes the study of the QGP, to ascertain its internal structure and interaction, extremely involved.

 

After a decade of exploratory studies, experiments are entering a phase of taking precision measurements of the QGP. The leading probe of the internal structure of this extreme form of matter has been the modification of jets and heavy-quarks (collectively referred to as hard probes). Jets are formed at the instant of collision, and begin as a single quark or gluon with an energy orders of magnitude higher than any other particle in the QGP.  Jets have been studied in particle collisions for decades, where the single quark or gluon decays into a collimated shower of particles in the vacuum. In a heavy-ion collision, these jets burrow through the plasma, where the shower is modified by scattering off the medium, and emerge from the QGP with depleted energy. Heavy quarks refer to quarks such as charm and bottom with masses that are orders of magnitude greater than those that form the QGP. The modification of the properties of jets and heavy quarks serve as windows into the internal structure of the plasma. The research funded by this award has resulted in major advancements in our understanding of these probes, as well as yielded new methods to carry out computer simulations of these effects.

 

Over the course of this award, a new method to numerically simulate the effect of the plasma on a hard quark was proposed and tested in the simplified environment of a static plasma confined in an enclosure, in equilibrium. This technique, referred to as lattice gauge theory, had been used to extract other properties of a high temperature plasma such as the energy density, but never been used to study the modification of a hard jet.

 

A new computer simulation routine was constructed to simulate the change in the shower process of a hard quark or gluon as it propagates and scatters in the dense medium. This new simulator called MATTER, has now become one of the standard routines that are being tested against experimental data from RHIC and the LHC. Based on the results of this simulator, a new observable was proposed: Jet mass modification in a QGP. The simulations revealed that contrary to conventional wisdom, jet mass could show a slight reduction for jets that have traversed a medium. This is currently being tested in experiments at the LHC.

 

The simulation routines were informed by several analytical calculations of the radiation pattern from jets undergoing multiple scattering in a medium, carried out over the course of the award. In close analogy to these, calculations were also carried out that showed that the scattering and radiation pattern of a heavy quark has a very different behavior at intermediate energies, a regime where the momentum is comparable to the mass, as compared to heavy quarks at high energy. These results may explain the striking suppression observed in the yield of such quarks in a heavy-ion collision.

 

Along with these, extensive phenomenological comparisons with experimental data were carried out. These revealed that while there is an increase in the density of the QGP at the higher energies afforded by the LHC, there is a weakening of the scattering strength between a jet and a constituent of the plasma at the LHC, compared to RHIC. Simulations were also extended to the collisions of protons with large nuclei where a new correlation between jet energy and particle production was observed. It was demonstrated, for the first time, that the production of a sufficiently high energy jet may deplete the yield of particles produced in the remainder of the collision.

 

The research mentioned above represents a portion of the advances made possible by this award. The award directly and indirectly influenced the training of 5 graduate students, 5 undergraduate students (via REU awards), and three postdoctoral fellows (not funded by the award). Beyond the scientific outcomes, the Principal investigator shepherded the origin of a seminar series conducted entirely by students and postdoctoral fellows at Wayne State University. Portions of the published research, were incorporated into a graduate course on nuclear physics.
